data.name: Collision Detection: Circle-Circle
data.description:
In this Kata, you will learn how to calculate collision detection between two circles. More about the collision detection in general can be read at [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_detection).

Each circle consists of radius and origin. The radius represents the distance between the center or origin of a circle and its perimiter or edge. The origin itself is the exact center of a circle.

Using this knowledge implement the algorithm that will precisely find if two circles have collided.

![Circle-Circle](http://i.imgur.com/OEOzAjZ.jpg)

# Details
## Task
Implement the `boolean isCollision(Circle a, Circle b)` method. This method must return `true` if the collision between two circles, `a` and `b`, is detected. Otherwise, it should return `false`.

## API

There are two classes at your disposal, `Point` and `Circle`.

### Point

Point class encapsulates the a pair of numerical coordinates in Cartesian coordinate system.

Method | Description
--- | ---
*Point(int x, int y)* | A constructor which initializes *Point* object based on a pair of numerical coordinates in Cartesian coordinate system.
*int getX()* | Returns the value for the horizontal distance of a point.
*int getY()* | Returns the value for the vertical distance of a point.

### Circle

Circle class encapsulates a geometric shape consisting of center point or origin and radius.

Method | Description
--- | ---
*Circle(Point center, int radius)* | A constructor which initializes *Circle* object based on its center *Point* and radius.
*Point getCenter()* | Returns the *Point* for circle exact origin - its center point.
*int getRadius()* | Returns the radius of the circle.
    
# Example

```java
CollisionDetection detector = new CollisionDetection();
Circle a = new Circle(new Point(0, 0), 1);
Circle b = new Circle(new Point(8, 0), 2);
```
Calling `detector.isCollision(a, b)` in above example should return `false`.
